items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at 10:00 on 03/03/22 at Gloucester.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore, low lying areas on Base Lane, Sandhurst. Sandhurst Lane will be just passable. The A417 at Maisemore may be closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.3m to 3.5m 02/03/22 at 22:00 and 3.6m to 3.9m on 03/03/22 at 10:15, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.5m 02/03/22 at 21:45 and 3.6m to 3.8m 03/03/22 at 10:00.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next 4 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.69mAOD at 15:00 on 02/03/22 and 4.60mAOD at 03:00 on 03/03/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 110 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain like this for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 12:00 on 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels are high but steady at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible while levels remain high. Flooding may affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. We expect river levels to remain high overnight and into tomorrow morning. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24hrs. Property flooding is not expected. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 3/3/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible this morning 02/03/2022, especially in the Passfield area. Further light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high but steady for the next few days. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 02/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of previous heavy rainfall  Consequently as a result of further forecast rainfall on Wednesday 02/03/22 and Thursday, flooding of farmland is expected to remain over the next few days. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high until 05/03/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning 02/03/22, especially in areas close to the River Thame in Thame. Further rainfall is forecast today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue to rise very slowly before stabilising over the next 24 hours. Levels on the Chalgrove Brook and River Thame upstream of Thame do not currently pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing weed/trash screens. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 02/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Dernford river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 02/03/2022.  We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 7 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high tonight and tomorrow, Thursday 03/03/2022.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 03/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are falling slowly at the Mythe Bridge and Upper Pound river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding is reducing. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours that may result in river levels remaining high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5pm on Thursday, 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 21:45 and 22:00 this Wednesday evening, 02/03/22 and 10:00 and 10:15 Thursday morning, 03/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.3m to 3.5m 02/03/22 at 22:00 and 3.6m to 3.9m on 03/03/22 at 10:15, Gloucester 3.3m to 3.5m 02/03/22 at 21:45 and 3.6m to 3.8m 03/03/22 at 10:00. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 03/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Pang and Sulham Brook as a result of the rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this morning 02/03/2022, especially in the Tidmarsh area. 
Further rainfall is forecast today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue to rise this morning before stabilising over the next 24 hours.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is expected later today 02/03/2022 and continuing tomorrow. Further light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated  this evening, 02/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Following the recent persistent rainfall, river levels are continuing to steadily rise on the River Clyst. 

Flooding of low lying land and roads close to the river is possible for the rest of today, Wednesday 2 March. No flooding to properties is currently forecast. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. 

We are constantly monitoring river levels and will update this message on Thursday morning, 3 March, or earlier if the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Hoe Stream as a result of persistent rainfall over the last few days. Therefore, flooding of some low lying roads and farmland is possible later this afternoon 02/03/22, and overnight.   
Further light rain is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall for the next few days. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 02/03/22, or as the situation changes.
